title: RECONNAISSANCE SOIL SURVEY OF THE BUSIA AREA
text:
The present soil survey is the eighth in series of “Reconnaissance Soil Surveys” with multipurpose land evaluation. The survey covers one toposheet (101) at scale 1:100,000. The survey area has a substantial variation in annual rainfall with a general increase of rainfall northward and eastward away from the area bordering Lake Victoria. The drier areas bordering Lake Victoria have only one rainy season viz:- March-May, whereas in the wetter areas, the rainfall distribution is bimodal viz:- March-May and August-December periods. The variation in rainfall to some extent reflects the land use pattern which varies from mainly grazing with crop cultivation in the low rainfall areas to mainly crop cultivation with grazing in the high rainfall areas.
The report shows that the general pattern of the soil resources is mainly determined by the physiographic position, the kind of bedrock (parent material) and climate. Most of the soils are strongly weathered and are generally acid in nature due to the leaching of the bases. They are dominantly low in calcium, potassium and organic matter and hence nitrogen.

title: Data Section Kenya Soil Survey
text:
The Kenya Soil Survey (KSS) provides soil data collected through rigorous field work, laboratory analysis, and spatial modelling.
This page explains how soil data are typically acquired, how soil properties are predicted and converted into maps, and how you can best explore the datasets available on this site.

title: Data Section Kenya Soil Survey
text:
1. How Soil Data Are Collected

Field Surveys
Soil data collection starts with structured field campaigns conducted across diverse landscapes in Kenya.
Typical activities include: - Site selection using stratified sampling, transects, or grid-based designs
- Soil profile description, including horizons, structure, colour, texture, and root distribution
- Auger observations collected at dense sampling intervals
- Geolocation using GPS/GNSS equipment
- Land use and vegetation notes
- Field photographs and sketches
Field teams follow standardized KSS procedures to ensure consistency and reproducibility.


Laboratory Analysis
Samples collected in the field are analysed in accredited laboratories to determine:

Soil pH

Organic carbon and organic matter

Nitrogen, phosphorus, potassium

Cation exchange capacity (CEC)

Texture (sand, silt, clay)

Micronutrients (Fe, Mn, Cu, Zn)

Bulk density

Mineralogical characteristics (where applicable)

Analytical methods align with national and international standards (FAO, USDA, ISO).

title: Data Section Kenya Soil Survey
section: 2. From Points to Maps: Predicting Soil Properties in Space
text:
2. From Points to Maps: Predicting Soil Properties in Space
Raw field and laboratory data represent point observations—specific measurements taken at specific locations.
To create continuous soil maps, KSS uses predictive soil mapping (also known as digital soil mapping).

Environmental Covariates
Spatial predictors are assembled from multiple sources, including:

Satellite imagery (e.g., vegetation indices, surface reflectance)

Climate surfaces (rainfall, temperature)

Terrain attributes (slope, curvature, elevation, topographic index)

Geological and parent material maps

Land cover and land use layers

These covariates help explain how soils vary across the landscape.


Predictive Modelling
Common modelling approaches include:

Random forest and gradient boosting models

Generalized additive models

Machine learning ensemble approaches

Geostatistical methods (e.g., regression-kriging)

Hybrid models combining machine learning and spatial interpolation

Models generate predictions and uncertainty layers, enabling users to understand confidence levels in each mapped product.


Map Production
The output maps include:

Soil property rasters at standard resolutions

Soil class maps based on classification systems (e.g., WRB, USDA)

Soil health indicator maps

Derived suitability layers (e.g., crop suitability, erosion risk)

Each map includes metadata detailing:

Data sources

Methods

Units

Accuracy statistics

Date of production

title: Data Section Kenya Soil Survey
text:
3. How to Explore the Data

Browsing the Dataset Library
You can explore datasets by visiting the Data or Downloads sections of this website.
Each dataset includes: - A description of its purpose
- Links to download raw or processed formats
- Metadata summaries
- Recommended software and tools for use


Exploring Maps Interactively
Many soil maps can be viewed using interactive map tools integrated into this site or external GIS tools such as:

QGIS

ArcGIS

Google Earth Engine

Web map viewers (Leaflet / Mapbox-based)

Interactive functions allow you to: - Zoom to your region of interest
- Click to view predicted values
- Overlay multiple soil layers
- Download map tiles or full-resolution rasters


Using Data for Decision-Making
The soil datasets support many applications, including:

Agricultural planning and crop suitability

Land restoration and conservation design

National and county-level environmental reporting

Academic research and modelling

Soil health monitoring

KSS encourages users to consult the accompanying documentation to correctly interpret data and understand limitations.

For recent field campaign summaries, see Publications.

title: About the Kenya Soil Survey
text:
The Kenya Soil Survey (KSS) is a national centre of excellence dedicated to the generation, analysis, and dissemination of soil and land resources information. As a department within the Kenya Agricultural and Livestock Research Organization (KALRO), KSS plays a central role in supporting sustainable agriculture, natural resource management, and environmental stewardship across Kenya.



The mandate of the Kenya Soil Survey includes:


Conduct systematic surveys, mapping, and characterization of soil and land resources at national, regional, and local scales.



Provide accredited laboratory services for soil, plant, and water analysis, ensuring reliable and standardized results.



Develop and maintain national soil databases, maps, and decision-support tools for researchers, policymakers, planners, and the public.



Advise on soil suitability, soil fertility management, land use planning, and sustainable agricultural intensification.



Support land restoration, climate change adaptation, and environmental conservation programs through soil monitoring and reporting.



Strengthen partnerships with counties, universities, regional and international organizations, and provide training in soil science and geospatial technologies.






To be a leading centre for soil and land resources information, enabling sustainable agricultural development and environmental management in Kenya.






To generate, analyse, and disseminate high-quality soil and land data through scientific research, innovation, and partnerships that support informed decision-making.





The Kenya Soil Survey has a long and distinguished history in Kenya’s agricultural and environmental research landscape.


KSS was established in the early 1970s to meet the growing need for detailed soil information for agricultural planning and land development. Early work focused on reconnaissance and semi-detailed surveys across major agricultural regions.



Throughout the 1980s and 1990s, KSS produced Kenya’s foundational soil maps and reports, many of which are still widely referenced. These included soil classification maps, land capability assessments, and agro-ecological studies.



From the 2000s onward, KSS modernized its operations, integrating digital soil mapping, GIS, remote sensing, and advanced laboratory technologies.
The digital era enabled the transition from traditional survey methods to modelling-based predictions and national-scale soil data products.



With the formation of the Kenya Agricultural and Livestock Research Organization (KALRO), KSS became a core department supporting national research, policy, and innovation systems.



Today, KSS is recognized as the national authority on soil information—supporting agriculture, climate action, land restoration, food security, and environmental monitoring through science-driven soil data.





KSS continues to innovate in:

Digital soil mapping and modelling

Soil health monitoring

Geospatial analysis and big data

Decision-support tools for farmers and planners

Open data and knowledge sharing

By advancing soil science and technology, the Kenya Soil Survey remains committed to improving livelihoods and ensuring sustainable use of Kenya’s land and soil resources.

title: Documentation
text:
This section provides detailed guidance on the procedures, standards, and workflows used by the Kenya Soil Survey (KSS).
Whether you are working with field data, laboratory analyses, or predictive soil mapping products, these documents will help you understand the methods behind the datasets.

title: Documentation
text:
1. Field Sampling Guidelines
Accurate, standardized field data are the foundation of high-quality soil information.
Our sampling guidelines cover:

Site Selection

Stratified sampling

Transects and grid-based approaches

Landscape and ecological stratification

Accessibility and safety considerations



Field Procedures

Soil profile excavation and horizon identification

Auger observations

Recording of colour, texture, structure, roots, stoniness, mottles

Georeferencing with GPS/GNSS

Field photography and metadata standards



Sample Handling

Sample labeling conventions

Storage and preservation requirements

Chain-of-custody procedures

A full Field Sampling Manual will be available for download here.

title: Documentation
text:
2. Laboratory Standards and Analytical Procedures
Laboratory analyses are performed using accredited and internationally recognized methods.

Analytical Methods
We follow national and international standards, including:
- ISO methods for chemical and physical analysis
- FAO and USDA soil testing procedures
- Standard operating protocols (SOPs) for KSS laboratories


Parameters Typically Analysed

pH (water and KCl)

Organic carbon

Total nitrogen

Available phosphorus & potassium

Cation exchange capacity (CEC)

Particle size distribution (texture)

Micronutrients (Zn, Cu, Mn, Fe)

Bulk density



Quality Assurance

Calibration procedures

Use of blanks, standards, and duplicates

Data validation workflows

A Laboratory Standards & SOPs document will be provided in this section.

title: Documentation
text:
3. Modelling Workflows for Soil Prediction
KSS uses digital soil mapping (DSM) approaches to transform point observations into continuous maps.

Modelling Framework
Workflows typically include:
- Data preprocessing
- Covariate assembly (satellite data, terrain models, climate layers, geology)
- Model selection and tuning
- Ensemble predictions
- Regression-kriging or hybrid geostatistical approaches


Output Products

Soil property rasters

Soil class maps

Soil health indicator layers

Uncertainty maps



Validation and Accuracy Assessment
We apply standard validation methods such as:
- k-fold cross-validation
- Independent test sets
- RMSE, R², CCC, and bias statistics
- Spatial cross-validation when appropriate


Reproducibility
All modelling workflows include:
- Metadata
- Version control
- Documentation of covariate sources and resolutions
- Traceable modelling scripts (available upon request)
A full Digital Soil Mapping Workflow Guide will be included here.

title: Documentation
text:
4. Metadata and Data Standards
All datasets include standardized metadata that describe: - Purpose of the dataset
- Sampling methodology
- Laboratory methods
- Spatial resolution and coordinate system
- Modelling methods
- Accuracy and limitations
- Citation guidelines
Metadata follow conventions aligned with FAO, ISO 19115, and national data-sharing policies.

title: RECONNAISSANCE SOIL SURVEY OF PART. OF THE MAKUENI AREA AND DETAILED SOIL SURVEY OF THE KAMPI YA MAWE
text: This report describes the results of a soil survey carried out in Kenya as part of a training on the job, in accordance with the requirements of the MSc-course in Soil Science and Water Management organized by the Agricultural University of Wageningen, The Netherlands. This practical exercise was carried out between 2nd September and 15th November 1974, during which period the author was in Kenya. Prior to soil mapping, a preliminary study was made of the geology, geomorphology, hydrology, climate, population and road pattern of the survey area. An analysis of the aerial photographs (scale 1:25,000) was done and a photointerpretation map was made. At the same time, the base map (scale 1:100,000) for the reconnaissance soil survey was prepared. Two types of soil surveys were carried out, namely, a detailed soil survey (scale 1:2,500) of Kampi ya Mawe Agricultural Experimental Substation and a reconnaissance soil mapping (scale 1:100,000) of a part of Makueni area. All the survey work, data collection and initial compilation of the soil maps and land suitability classification maps were done in Kenya. The report was prepared in Wageningen after the fieldwork. Chapters 3 through 7 of this report give information about the reconnaissance survey, chapter. 8 is devoted to the detailed survey.
